Even in Emerson's own day the word "transcenden- talism" was considered confusing, and the popular meaning of the word is still "vague, obscure, visionary." Scholars accustomed to exact knowledge could not make head or tail of Emerson's school of thought. That was not surprising. Transcendentalism had no system; it was more poetry than thought. "What is popularly called transcendentalism among us is idealism," Emerson once said.
